awd_titl_txt: Preparing Secondary Mathematics Teachers with Video Cases of Students' Functional Reasoning
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to address a critical area of mathematics, function, which is a unifying concept in K-12 mathematics that applies to the study of algebra, geometry, probability, and statistics, but persists as a challenge for students.  To this end, this project will develop a series of video-based online learning modules for use in undergraduate mathematics courses so that prospective secondary mathematics teachers (PSMTs) are better equipped to recognize, analyze, and make connections between the patterns found in students' functional reasoning.  Many students leave high school with serious limitations in their ability to reason with functions.  At the same time, teacher education programs are faced with the challenge of preparing teachers to teach in ways that build upon the informal knowledge students bring to the classroom.  Teachers who are adept at building upon students' ideas have a specialized knowledge of how mathematical ideas are related, how to represent ideas in meaningful ways, and common patterns in students' reasoning. This type of mathematical knowledge cannot be developed through field-based work alone. 

The theoretical foundation for this project arises from (1) students' informal and formal reasoning related to key mathematical ideas, (2) students' thinking about functions, (3) the use of video to engage PSMTs in learning about student thinking, and (4) the design and use of video-based learning environments which feature online components.  Using a design-based research methodology, the first two years of this project will focus on the development and beta-testing of four video modules in an undergraduate mathematics course designed for PSMTs.  The final two years of the project will focus on the dissemination and implementation of these modules at partner UTeach institutions, as well as the study of data emanating from the implementation.  Throughout the project, about 250 PSMTs and 20 university instructors will engage with the modules.  The completed module series will provide teacher education programs a straightforward way to integrate mathematical content specific to teaching within their existing mathematics curriculum while simultaneously increasing well-designed hybrid learning opportunities at the undergraduate level.  Through evaluation and research, the project will result in (1) an empirically-based model for PSMT learning about student thinking in the context of the module learning environments, and (2) theory and design principles for supporting PSMT learning with video cases of student thinking.  Information about the project, its materials, and its outcomes will be shared with local and national educational audiences via research publications, conference presentations, and university instructor workshops.  This project is supported under the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) program and the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program, with the goal of helping to improve secondary mathematics teacher preparation through implementation of online video modules that highlight carefully selected cases of student thinking.  This project will enable teacher educators to better equip their undergraduate PSMTs in making functional reasoning accessible to a broad population of students, thereby potentially broadening student participation in STEM fields.

por.por_cntn:
In 2017, Boise State University received a $1.6 million NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education award entitled, “Preparing Secondary Mathematics Teachers With Video Cases of Students’ Functional Reasoning (VCAST).” Using a design-based research approach, the VCAST project developed four curricular modules for use in undergraduate mathematics courses for future secondary mathematics teachers. Over the life of the project, over 500 university students engaged with the VCAST materials, through module implementation by 21 instructors at 17 universities across the country. Products include the four online curriculum modules hosted in Moodle (an open source mobile friendly learning management system), one online article, 29 conference presentations, including 10 conference proceedings, six professional workshops for teachers, three book chapters, three journal articles, with three manuscripts under development.

Each VCAST module consists of two asynchronous online components along with a synchronous face-to-face component, designed to support teacher attentiveness to students’ ideas in the following ways: (1) recognizing that students can shift and/or use multiple approaches or understanding, (2) recognizing that initial assumptions about students’ understanding, approach, or perception of problem difficulty may be incorrect, (3) identifying specific complexity components of non-traditional mathematics tasks, and (4) improving mathematical knowledge about the concepts embedded within a task. Qualitative analysis of module responses has focused on how particular module design elements contribute (or inhibit) future teachers’ learning. For instance, each module engages candidates in reflective cycles involving analysis of student evidence, making predictions about next steps or assessments of student understanding, and then revisiting initial claims after additional student evidence (often with the potential to contradict earlier assumptions) is made available. Engagement in these cycles appears to help future teachers learn that initial assessments of student thinking may be faulty and that seeking additional information, asking questions, searching for evidence of productive reasoning, and adopting a stance of humility can be more beneficial for student learning. Attentiveness, defined as the ability to analyze and productively respond to evidence of an individual student’s thinking, relies upon not only a teacher’s knowledge for teaching and of mathematics, but also the degree to which teachers are willing to question their own assumptions, retain an open perspective when analyzing and evaluating student efforts, and to seek additional information from the students whom they teach.

VCAST modules are available to university faculty and professional development leaders, at no cost, and by request via https://www.boisestate.edu/vcast-project/. Collectively, the modules address a range of key mathematical ideas, including coupling two quantities graphically, comparing relationally-specified quantities, reasoning with explicit versus recursive defined functions, working in discrete versus continuous contexts, using figural versus numerical approaches in the context of figural patterned sequences, coordinating change associated with two co-varying quantities, and understanding the ideas involved with creating mathematical models for nonlinear real-word data. Partner instructors have regularly reported that their own knowledge and skills were supported through implementing the VCAST modules, even though instructor development was not an explicit goal of the project (Cavey, Totorica, DuCloux, et al., 2022; Cavey, Naresh, et al., 2021). In particular, instructors described how a focus on analysis of student thinking helped improve their own (a) knowledge of the range of ways students solve problems, (b) math understanding, and (c) instruction. In addition, partner instructors have reported benefits for the mathematical learning of the general mathematics student who does not intend to pursue secondary teaching. 

In summary, with respect to broader impacts, the VCAST project has (1) improved secondary math teacher candidates’ (a) understanding of key ideas related to functions and math modeling, (b) ability to analyze secondary students’ ideas, and (c) pedagogical stance oriented towards students as a source of knowledge, (2) improved math teacher educator pedagogical stance and knowledge, and (3) improved secondary math students’ learning experiences.With respect to intellectual merit, the VCAST project has generated (1) design knowledge with respect to developing online video-based curriculum made available in a user-friendly platform, (2) teacher candidate response data and analysis, and (3) instrument development related to measure teacher candidates’ attentiveness to student mathematical ideas.
